user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__timeout:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__timeout (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail,
                        const char *next_param)
{
  unsigned int param_value;
  enum PerfRepl_param_result value_res;

  value_res = get_param_value (param_name, param_tail, next_param,
                               &param_value);
  if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR == value_res)
    return value_res;

  tool_params.timeout = param_value;
  return value_res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in this code. The parameters (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail, const char *next_param) are only passed to get_param_value and are not assigned to, incremented, or otherwise modified; their const qualification further indicates the function does not alter the pointed-to objects. The only pointer passed for modification is &param_value (address of a local variable), which is permitted because the rule allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter (here the callee may write into the provided storage), and that object is a local, not a function parameter. The assignment to tool_params.timeout affects a global structure member, not any function parameter. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
